thread.title: English says saving to back up NZ Super fruitless - NZ First
thread.title_full: English says saving to back up NZ Super fruitless - NZ First

author: Fuseworks Media
title: English says saving to back up NZ Super fruitless - NZ First
text:
Fuseworks Media Tuesday, 20 October, 2015 - 14:45 
The Cullen Fund, the country’s savings for peak demand on NZ Super, does not work, according to Finance Minister Bill English. 
Asked by New Zealand First about National’s failure to keep up contributions to the fund over a decade, Mr English brazenly claimed the government did not keep spending taxpayers’ money on anything that did not work, says New Zealand First Leader and Member of Parliament for Northland Rt Hon Winston Peters. 
The Cullen Fund, officially the New Zealand Superannuation Fund, has been rated the top sovereign investment fund performer in the world, says Mr Peters. 
"Had National kept up the taxpayers’ contributions, it would be now worth $18.2 billion more than it is now at $29.6 billion. 
"National should be ashamed that of the $14.5 billion of capital contributions made National has been responsible for just 2 per cent. 
"As National borrows heavily to pay for election bribe tax cuts, the population is ageing and the fund set up to cushion the hit on NZ super is not growing as fast as it could. 
"National is being irresponsible and short-changing New Zealanders who will claim the pension in decades to come," says Mr Peters.
